title: Dona Ana County, NM
text:
Economic Development Projects
Project Jupiter is a large-scale data center campus proposed for development in Doña Ana County, in Santa Teresa, New Mexico. The project is being led by STACK Infrastructure in partnership with BorderPlex Digital Assets. With an estimated total investment of up to $165,000,000,000 it represents one of the most significant private-sector infrastructure initiatives in the region’s history.
Industrial Revenue Bonds (IRB)
In the State of New Mexico, an IRB helps attract jobs and investment by offering a tax abatement, and it doesn’t place a financial risk on the Government entity authorizing it. It’s a common tool used by other communities to stay competitive in attracting major projects.
What is an Industrial Revenue Bond, IRB?
It is a common economic development tool used by states and local governments to attract businesses that will bring jobs to an area. The participating companies fund the project. When a company gets an IRB approved, they won’t pay property taxes during the time the IRB is in place but will almost always have to make “payment in lieu of taxes” (PILOT).
Why Would a Government Entity Issue an IRB for a project?
A Government entity uses IRBs as a tool to attract projects; Doña Ana County has issued many IRBs in the past to support companies, either for expansion of their operations or to attract new businesses.
Industrial Revenue Bond (IRB) Life Cycle
|
Milestone |
Explanation |
|
1. Application |
Company submits application. County reviews application, checking if project benefits the community. |
|
2. Application |
Company pays a $25,000 application fee, which helps cover the County’s processing costs. |
|
3. County Bond Attorney |
Represents the County in the bond process |
|
4. Negotiation |
Negotiate IRB terms and determine PILOT = Payment in Lieu of Taxes, which are special payments instead of property taxes. |
|
5. 30-Day Notice Letters |
County notifies all entities that levy property taxes within the county. - Sent to County Assessor and any entity located within the County authorized to levy property taxes in the County.
- Must be mailed at least 30 days prior to final consideration of the Bond Ordinance.
- Sent by certified mail, return receipt requested.
- Notice includes amount, purpose and the time period of proposed IRB
|
|
6. Inducement Resolution |
County votes to begin the IRB process and publication of hearing notice. |
|
7. Public Hearing Notice of Intent to Consider Ordinance |
Published in local newspaper at least 14 days before Bond Ordinance consideration meeting. |
|
8. Bond Ordinance Consideration |
County Commission considers Bond Ordinance and, if approved by the Commission, authorizes the issuance of the IRBs. |
|
9. Publish Notice of Bond Adoption |
30-day period of limitation of action. County finalizes agreements and closing documents during this time. |
|
10. Closing/ Project Conveyed |
Documents signed. Financing starts. Earliest = 30 days after notice of adoption of Bond Ordinance publication. Ownership of project property transferred (bare legal title) to County. County leases project property back to Company under the IRB Lease |
|
11. During IRB term |
Company leases property back from the County and makes Rent payments under the IRB Lease to repay the Bonds. Company also makes PILOT payments. |
|
12. Repayment |
Bonds repaid over long term, which depends on IRB terms. |
|
13. Final Maturity of Bonds |
Face value of Bonds repaid to bond purchasers. |
|
14. End of IRB Term |
County transfers property to Company and the Company begins paying property taxes on the project property. |
Safeguards
- Facilities Closure Claw Backs: If company closes early, it must repay all or a portion of tax breaks.
- Job Targets: Company must meet promised employment goals and failure to meet them results in repayment of tax breaks or increased PILOT payments, based upon agreement structure.
- Certain Defaults by Company: The County can terminate the IRB Lease and transfer the property back to the Company, putting the property back on the tax rolls.

title: Local Community Sues Doña Ana County to Stop Billions of Tax Dollars Going to OpenAI Data Center

Thursday, October 23, 2025
Lawsuit Cites Project Jupiter’s Incomplete and Inadequate Application
Las Cruces, NM—On Friday, October 17, 2025, the New Mexico Environmental Law Center, on behalf of Empowerment Congress of Doña Ana County; José Saldaña Jr., resident of Sunland Park; and Vivian Fuller, resident of Santa Teresa, filed a lawsuit in the Third Judicial District Court against the Doña Ana County Board of County Commissioners for their unlawful approval of three ordinances related to Project Jupiter, the massive hyperscale data center proposed in Santa Teresa, New Mexico. …

title: Community group sues Doña Ana County Commissioners over Project Jupiter approval
text:
Community group sues Doña Ana County Commissioners over Project Jupiter approval
LAS CRUCES, N.M. (KFOX14/CBS4) —A community organization and two residents have filed a lawsuit against the Doña Ana County Board of Commissioners, alleging the county violated state and local law when it approved ordinances tied to the proposed $165 billion Project Jupiter data center in Santa Teresa.
The complaint, filed Oct. 17 in the Third Judicial District Court by the New Mexico Environmental Law Center, represents Empowerment Congress of Doña Ana County and residents José Saldaña Jr. of Sunland Park and Vivian Fuller of Santa Teresa.
The lawsuit challenges three ordinances adopted by the county commission.
The first authorizes the issuance of $165 billion in Industrial Revenue Bonds (IRBs) for the project.
The second and third ordinances authorize Local Economic Development Act (LEDA) funding to support Project Jupiter, including anticipated permit fees.
Commissioners approved the measures in two separate 4-1 votes in September and October, with Commissioner Susana Chaparro voting against both times.
RELATED: Doña Ana County approves $165 billion AI data center despite protests and calls for delay
Plaintiffs claim the county relied on a single, incomplete application from Project Jupiter’s developers that contained blank and missing pages and lacked critical information necessary to make a fully informed decision.
The filing also states that county officials held private meetings with the project’s developers months before the public hearings and signed a non-disclosure agreement earlier this year.
Plaintiffs argue that these actions limited transparency and prevented residents from fully understanding the project before the votes.
The lawsuit seeks judicial review of the ordinances, a court order invalidating the county’s approval, and a stay halting implementation while the case proceeds.
Project Jupiter, led by Borderplex Digital Assets, would include a hyperscale data center, microgrid, battery storage, and a desalination plant.
County officials have previously described the project as one of the largest potential commercial developments in New Mexico history, with the potential to bring thousands of jobs.
Community members and environmental advocates have raised concerns about the project’s potential strain on water and energy resources and its impacts on surrounding neighborhoods, as well as the longevity of the jobs the center would bring.
The full press release can be found on the New Mexico Environmental Law Center website.
We have reached out to each of the County Commissioners for comment and have not heard back.
We will keep you updated both on air and online when new details arise.
RELATED: Project Jupiter ignites debate: Economic tech boom or ecological bane for Borderland?

title: Meta data center in East El Paso concerns local residents
text:
EL PASO, Texas — A new AI-optimized Meta data center is taking shape in far East El Paso. While supporters tout billions in investment and hundreds of new jobs, residents nearby are voicing serious concerns about water usage, electricity and the effects on their neighborhoods.
The data center is currently under construction in the northeast part of the city of El Paso. Meta says it selected El Paso for its workforce, available open land and access to renewable energy. As the project advances, many in this community are now asking questions about how they’ll be affected by one of the region’s largest tech investments.
In the desert area on the outskirts of the city, the massive 1.2 million-square-foot facility is now under construction. It’s the tech giant’s future data center, a project Jon Barela of the Borderplex Alliance —an organization focused on economic development in El Paso, Las Cruces, New Mexico and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico—says has been in the works for four years.
“It is one of the best world companies, so to have them here it’s an absolute honor here in El Paso County, and we are thrilled to have them and welcome them here.” Barela said.
He describes Meta’s arrival as a turning point for the region and the result of years of work to position El Paso as a hub for advanced data and AI infrastructure.
“I have been working with other valued community partners, elected officials, the city and county levels, and of course, our utilities El Paso Water, and El Paso Electric, which are very much part of this team to locate this project, which would be at least $1.5 billion initial investment with hopefully many more billions to come,” he said.
Barela says he has witnessed the impact firsthand. In 2016, he helped recruit Meta to build its first New Mexico data center in Los Lunas.
“Their construction is complete, and thousands of jobs have been created in that area. The population has grown at a good rate there in central New Mexico, and there have been many positive things that have happened,” he said.
But it’s Barela’s work with El Paso Water and El Paso Electric that many in this community are most interested in. The new facility will require large amounts of electricity to cool its servers.
El Paso is not on the Texas grid managed by the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT). But while Meta says the site will operate on 100% renewable energy, neighbors worry it could still strain the local power grid.
Water usage has sparked even greater controversy. Meta’s design relies on evaporative cooling. Initial estimates suggest the facility could consume up to 1.5 billion gallons of water each year, an amount that residents fear may affect water availability and raise rates.
“It’s good that they are bringing another company, and it’s good that they are bringing job opportunities, but to take 1.5 billion gallons of water for the community, I think they need to research that more and possibly find a better way to do it instead of taking out the water from homeowners,” said Richard Herrera, a neighbor to the data center.
El Paso Water insists the region can manage the increased demand, stating the final system design will require much less water than initially estimated and that Meta will cover the full cost of any necessary infrastructure upgrades. However, for families already coping with rising utility bills, the ongoing uncertainty is troubling.
“It’s very bad, and also when there is too much water using the bills are going up again, every year they go up, and that’s not good for the people who work for our families, and having bills too high is not good,” said Martin Ramos, another neighbor of the data center.
Meta says the project will create 1,200 construction jobs at its peak and approximately 100 long-term positions, while generating millions in local tax revenue. Construction is expected to continue through 2028.

title: Dona Ana County, NM
text:
About Us
Doña Ana County is the second largest county in the state of New Mexico. With a population of more than 219,500 residents, the County comprises 3,814 square miles, bordering El Paso County in Texas, Luna and Otero Counties in New Mexico and the state of Chihuahua, in Mexico. It is home to the Cities of Anthony, Las Cruces and Sunland Park; the Town of Mesilla and the Village of Hatch.
Our agricultural community has a significant place in Doña Ana County, making us a leading producer of chile peppers, onions and pecans. We are also home to the New Mexico State University and Doña Ana Community College.
The Mesilla Valley, the Organ Mountains Desert Peaks National Monument and the White Sands National Monument are some of our historic points of interest. Doña Ana County's history is intertwined with the U.S. Army's, which built forts throughout the nation's border with Mexico, enabling many settlements, ranches, mining camps and homestead to flourish and helped shape our landscape.

text:
OUR WORK
AIR
The Law Center represents residents in their battle to fend off polluting industry and preserve their right to clean air.
LAND
The Law Center serves communities fighting to keep dangerous pollutants away from their land and clean up areas already contaminated.
WATER
In the face of the added urgent threat from climate change, protecting both access to water and quality of water is a critical priority for the Law Center.
We won’t back down. We won’t stop fighting.
They only win when we give up. And we are not giving up.
Our work and the fight continues.
We will keep showing up alongside our clients and communities fighting for our people and Mother Earth.
OUR MISSION
The New Mexico Environmental Law Center has been defending environmental justice since 1987. It is our mission to work with New Mexico’s communities to protect their air, land and water in the fight for environmental justice.
At the Law Center, we are working hard with under-resourced communities in New Mexico to ensure that they have the same clean air, land and water that every New Mexican is entitled to. We are on the legal front line fighting to not only keep environmental regulations, but to make them even stronger. Support our work to protect New Mexico.
The New Mexico Environmental Law Center is committed to dismantling the racist structures that are at the heart of environmental injustice and all disparate treatment of communities of color. If we do not respect the water we drink, the air we breathe, the land we sow, and the community in which we live, we cannot realize the fundamental human rights to which we are all entitled. We stand with those seeking justice and will continue to utilize our platform to support our state and its people.
Note: the Law Center is currently only considering requests for assistance on a limited basis.
Congratulations to our Executive Director!
Congratulations to all the awardees of the Rachel’s Network Catalyst Award, including our very own Executive Director, Dr. Virginia Necochea!
This award honors women leaders of color for their commitment to a healthy planet and, according to Rachel’s Network President Fern Shepard, “This year’s awardees and finalists demonstrate that women of color are catalyzing change across our field, from environmental justice and energy equity to marine science and health. Their leadership is transforming our world for the better.”
Rachel’s Network, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit named in honor of Rachel Carson, is a community of women at the intersection of environment, philanthropy, and women’s leadership who exchange ideas and take action on our planet’s urgent challenges.
Congrats Dr. Necochea!
IMPORTANT ARTICLES
ENVIRONMENTAL RACISM
Many people understand the environment as a force of nature that cannot favor or disfavor different populations. However, similar to all things on Earth, the environment is subject to human influences. Unfortunately, these influences often tend to lower their hands to the worsts of our society including racism and classism. This can ultimately create environmental racism…
REJECT HIDDEN MINING APPROVALS IN COVID-19 RELIEF LEGISLATION
Hard rock mining is considered to be the most toxic industry in the US. That’s why a nationwide coalition of environmental & public health advocates are calling on Congress to reject hidden industry handouts in the COVID-19 relief package…
NEW MEXICO RULES ON FRACKING
Environmentalists leveled sharp criticisms at rules dealing with recycled water produced during oil and gas extraction in New Mexico. Environmentalists also criticized regulators for offering a rule they claim is too narrow to address environmental and public health concerns and abdicates responsibility to other state personnel who also don’t have a rule that addresses their worries…
WHY WE SUPPORT THE CLIMATE EQUITY ACT
Since 1987, the New Mexico Environmental Law Center has worked alongside communities in our state in the name of environmental justice. Our staff and attorneys pursue legislation and court battles on behalf of clients, working on cases that often take years of court filings and appeals to wind their way through the legal system.
In Solidarity with Protestors…
The events of the last weeks – which have their origins in the very beginning of our nation’s history – have laid bare the inequities that are the mainstay of America. The state sponsored violence is vicious and jarring and has resulted in widespread popular resistance. The New Mexico Environmental Law Center unequivocally condemns police violence and stands in solidarity with the communities impacted by police violence and the Black Lives Matter movement.
The massive protest against police violence and systemic racism also provides a glimpse into the more mundane, but equally caustic, day to day violence that existing racist structures perpetuate. The daily machinery of oppression includes the wide array of environmental and public health laws that mediate how each of us relates to the larger global ecosystem.
While our nation’s environmental laws are held up as a bastion of progressivism, they do not serve everyone equally. The environmental movement is rooted in the privilege of affluence and whiteness that has historically excluded communities of color.
We in the environmental movement are often the beneficiaries of the privileges that at the same time oppress our neighbors and allies. It would be easy for the Law Center to retweet a statement from a frontline organization or post something on our website expressing outrage at the latest incidents of state violence and then go about our lives. It’s much more difficult and important to engage in meaningful and thoughtful evaluation of our place in the framework that perpetuates violence and oppression.
We believe, however, that only with a hard look at ourselves and the system we work in can we begin to really understand and resist the systemic racist structures that dictate who has clean water, air and land and who must pay the price for industrial “progress” that ostensibly benefits us all, but in reality only serves a few. At the Law Center, we acknowledge that we have benefited from the status quo and have begun the difficult and essential process necessary to become a more equitable and inclusive organization. We are having conversations both internally and with community partners to identify ways in which we may have perpetuated oppressive structures and find ways to address our shortcomings to become better partners with communities.
We also call on our white friends and colleagues to reject the easy tropes that “environmental laws protect everyone” or “governments are well meaning” and to truly examine our system of environmental law and policy and ask whether it also contributes to the day to day violence that communities of color live with. We call on our friends and colleagues to consider that environmentalism is more than protecting a scenic area for recreation or aesthetic beauty, but is also a fundamental struggle to ensure human and civil rights to the basic conditions necessary for survival and human dignity. We call on our white friends and colleagues to listen deeply to communities of color; to step up when called to, to step back when asked and to stand in solidarity no matter what.
Law Center Client
Red Water Pond Community
As World War Two was ending, the growing nuclear arms race put the US in need of uranium. It turned to Navajo Nation, where the uranium mining industry thrived for four decades — but left disease, pollution and the biggest radioactive spill in US history. That spill in Church Rock, New Mexico upended the lives of nearby residents, who had to grapple with toxic water, livestock and a lifetime of illnesses. Now, they are still waiting for it to be cleaned up.

title: OUR WORK
text:
Our Clients:
“We see you as being instrumental in holding mining companies’ feet to the fire in terms of environmental accountability.”
“The Law Center is invaluable in protecting our environment and environmental laws…We greatly appreciate what the Law Center has helped do in the Southwest.”
“It’s about time someone in a position of power called out the Commissioners…who disrespect us, mislead us, and step over us on behalf of the developers.”

title: Air
text:
Industrial and mining activities that pollute the air steal years away from the people who live nearby.
Those who live in low-income neighborhoods and neighborhoods of color die younger than their counterparts in richer, whiter neighborhoods. The Law Center represents residents in these communities in their battle to fend off polluting industry and preserve their right to clean air.
Honstein Fuel Depot
Case: Closed Our clients in this case challenged the Albuquerque-Bernalillo County Joint Air Quality Control Board’s method of permitting a 6,000 gallon gasoline storage tank that is located near homes in the San Jose neighborhood.
Title VI Complaint over air quality in Albuquerque, Bernalillo County
Case: Closed. The City of Albuquerque and Bernalillo County have a track record of permitting air polluting facilities in low-income neighborhoods of color. NMELC and its clients are advocating for healthy air in the neighborhoods through local and federal action. One such effort was a federal civil rights complaint filed against the City and County. In 2016, the EPA agreed to investigate our allegations.

title: Land
text:
The land is our home. It’s where we live, play, work and dream.
Environmental degradation and disregard affects all of us: on public and private lands, urban and rural communities, and indigenous ancestral homes. The Law Center serves communities fighting to keep dangerous pollutants away from their land and clean up areas already contaminated.
Mount Taylor Mine Return to Active Status
Case: Ongoing The Cold War-era Mount Taylor uranium mine stopped producing in 1990, although it continues to leak contamination into groundwater. This case is a test of how the state’s Mining Act is enforced against “zombie” mines – mines that neither produce ore nor clean up.
LANL Cleanup Consent Order Failure
Case: Closed Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) missed multiple deadlines and accrued up to $300 million in fines under its 2005 Consent Order to clean up Cold War-era contamination. Governor Martinez’ New Mexico Environment Department (NMED) refused to enforce it and sought to repeal it with a new Consent Order in 2016.

title: Water
text:
Nine out of ten New Mexicans get their drinking water from groundwater —
yet oil and gas drilling, mining, nuclear weapons production, ill-considered development and lax industry practices threaten our state’s scarce resources.
Santolina Proposed Development
Case: Ongoing We represent community groups in their effort to prevent approval for a 90,000+ person planned development proposed for the west side of Albuquerque – despite the fact that developers have failed to show where they will get their water and how they will construct this massive undertaking without cost to Bernalillo taxpayers.
Surface and Groundwater Quality Protection Regulation Amendments
Case: Closed The Martinez Administration’s NM Environment Department proposed numerous changes to the state’s surface water and groundwater quality regulations. Many of them would reduce public notice and hinder public participation.

title: Stories
text:
Stories
Larry’s Story
Larry J. King of Church Rock once worked in the mines that line the Rio Puerco between Red Water Pond Road Community and Church Rock. The United Nuclear spill of 1979 into the Rio Puerco – the largest accidental release of radiation in US history – surged through the land that he and his family call home. He joined ENDAUM in its early days, and has become a leader in the fight to prevent new uranium mining in Diné communities. Following are excerpts from a video interview with Larry.
“When I first joined in 1997, I didn’t see myself twenty years down the road, or even several years later, working on this. I thought maybe it would be resolved in three years – no more than 10 years. But twenty years later, we’re still here. It’s a long and hideous process. A lot of sleepless nights. A lot of worries.”
“Our organization, with the help of the Law Center and other groups, was able to educate our elected Tribal officials and our President at the time… We were also successful in getting a Navajo Nation law passed to ban uranium mining in Navajo Country.”
“A total ban on new uranium mining… and cleanup. Compensate the workers [who worked in the industry after 1971 who do not qualify for the federal Radiation Exposure Compensation Act]. That would be justice.”
“Advice for communities just starting a fight against a big polluter: be persistent, be vigilant, don’t give up. Your first target would be your elected officials. Target them, educate them. From there, once you get all of those people on your side, it’s easy.”
“If the Law Center disappeared…that would be a huge, tremendous loss. We’d have to start from ground zero. I would be forever in shock because the companies that we’ve been so far lucky to keep away from our communities, once they found out, they would come charging in. That would be a huge catastrophe.”
“To all the people who donate to keep the NMELC going, I extend my deep appreciation.” – Larry J. King

title: ABOUT THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL LAW CENTER
text:
ABOUT THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL LAW CENTER
New Mexico Environmental Law Center
is a non profit, public interest law firm that provides free and low-cost legal services on environmental matters throughout New Mexico. Founded in 1987, the Law Center works with clients — often individuals, neighborhood associations, environmental organizations, Tribes and Pueblos — seeking to protect the environment.
The New Mexico Environmental Law Center’s mission
is to protect New Mexico’s communities and their air, land and water in the fight for environmental justice. The Law Center’s effective legal advocacy and representation on environmental and environmental justice issues will protect New Mexico’s communities and cultures, and ensure clean air, land and water for all. The work of the Law Center is made possible by tax-deductible contributions from individuals, business, foundations and limited earned income.

title: Take Action
text:
This reckless disregard for our state’s groundwater, coupled with the impact of global warming, is rapidly moving us toward a crisis situation!
Here at the Law Center, we are especially concerned because 80-90% of New Mexicans rely on groundwater for their drinking water. And once groundwater is polluted, it is extremely difficult and costly to clean up! Accordingly, over 70% of the casework we do is focused on protecting the quantity and quality of our state’s groundwater.
Why We’re Raising Money Now
Environmental justice work remains as critical as ever, even during this disruptive time. You may have read that the EPA suspended enforcement of vital environmental regulations that protect our air, land, and water. As a result, people in communities who have lived for decades with debilitating air and water pollution face an even greater risk of severe health issues.
NMELC is working hard to protect vulnerable communities. We are on the legal front line fighting to not only keep environmental regulations, but to make them even stronger. It is because of your generosity that we can keep up the fight. Now, maybe more than ever, we need your support to fight the very long court battles ahead.

title: Future Giving
text:
LEGACY GIVING
A charitable gift made through a will or other estate plan provides a critical source of financial support for the Law Center, helping ensure that we can advocate effectively for communities and the environment for many years to come.
With our 30th anniversary year under our belt, the New Mexico Environmental Law Center has notched many environmental and community victories. Since our founding in 1987, the need we address – to protect New Mexico’s natural resources and communities – has not lessened. Some cases remain active decades after they’ve begun, and we continue to fight to prevent degradation and contamination of air, land and water and defend against threats to community health. Long-term gift planning is critical to our forward-thinking vision.
You may choose to give a gift through your will because:
- you feel you can make a larger gift down the road than you can make today
- you want to continue to make a difference to the Law Center’s work far beyond your lifetime
Join the Meiklejohn Legacy Circle
The Meiklejohn Legacy Circle includes all supporters who provide for the Law Center in their wills or other estate plans. A gift planned now to be realized after your lifetime can establish your legacy well into the future. You can earmark a gift for a specific program area, or allow the Law Center to allocate it where it is most needed. In either case, such a gift will help ensure that the Law Center can field a legal team and support staff to continue protecting New Mexico’s air, water, land and ways of life for as long as such work is needed.
There are many ways to make a planned gift. Bequests are the simplest and most common form, and can be stated as a specific dollar amount, a percentage of assets, or the residual of an estate. Cash or certain other tangible assets can also be transferred through a retirement plan, life insurance, or a charitable trust. Some giving options, such as charitable trusts, can also provide income during your lifetime to you or a loved one. Please talk with your attorney or tax adviser to review options that will offer the most beneficial scenario for you.
No gift is too small; every gift makes a difference! Thank you for helping ensure that the Law Center and its work to protect New Mexico’s resources and its people will continue.

title: Current EJ Business Partners

BECOME AN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE BUSINESS PARTNER!
Our Green Business Partners Program is now our Environmental Justice Business Partners Program!
Environmental Justice (EJ) Business Partners are supporters of the New Mexico Environmental Law Center (NMELC), who are deeply committed to protecting New Mexico’s air, land, and water and placing frontline communities at the center of the conversation.
At NMELC, we center environmental justice throughout our work—the principle that all people, regardless of socioeconomic status, race or ethnicity, have the fundamental right to live in a clean and healthy environment. Our EJ Business Partners are critical to ensuring that the important environmental justice work at NMELC continues strong.
In recognition of the generous financial support, EJ Business Partners are included in various NMELC communications including our social media platforms and in newsletters reaching over 2,000 people every week. We invite you to highlight your business commitment to New Mexico’s environment and communities through an annual gift at a level that aligns with your business. Past EJ Business Partners have contributed at $500 to over $5,000.
In-kind donations are also accepted and appreciated. Past in-kind donors have given specific services and goods equal to the amounts listed above for recognition.
EJ Business Partners strengthen and support NMELC’s ability to take on precedent-setting cases that protect our communities from environmental hazards and pollution. NMELC proudly offers free to low-cost legal services to clients and communities who are defending our environment and are upholding environmental justice. It is our privilege to represent and work alongside the many clients and communities we serve.
Our Environmental Justice Business Partners are honored in the following ways:
- Recognition in the Annual Impact Report, delivered by mail, email, and available on our website

title: “To say that the New Mexico Environmental Law Center is an asset to the state is an understatement. ”
text:
“To say that the New Mexico Environmental Law Center is an asset to the state is an understatement. ”
“The center represents those who have no other advocate, leveling the playing field so that ordinary citizens have a chance to prevail against odds that are stacked against them. Here in the Augustin Plains, for example, we face an international corporation with deep pockets that is intent on mining water from an aquifer of fossil water that sustains the residents and the economy of Catron County…
The project of the Augustin Plains Ranch LLC would, if approved, pump 54,000 acre-feet of water – 17 billion gallons – per year from the aquifer, put that water in a pipeline and ship it to the Albuquerque area… This amount of pumping from the aquifer would deplete it in a finite amount of time, and the people here in Catron County would be left literally ‘high and dry’… The New Mexico Environmental Law Center stands on the front line with us, helping to safeguard our future.
Should the project be approved, that approval would set the stage for such projects across the state, and rural communities would find themselves fighting similar battles. It is of the utmost importance to keep the New Mexico Environmental Law Center alive and vibrant, giving our communities a fighting chance to preserve our water which will by extension preserve our culture, our way of life, our economy, and the environment, which, indeed, makes all life possible.”
–Quotes taken from Carol’s letter to the editor of the Albuquerque Journal published November 17, 2017.

title: NMELC Letter to Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham Urging to Halt Tritium Venting
text:
September 12, 2025
Via email: michelle@newmexicansformichelle.com
Re: Urgent call to halt Los Alamos National Laboratory’s Saturday, September 13, 2025
tritium venting
Governor Lujan Grisham:
This letter serves as an urgent call to halt Los Alamos National Laboratory’s (LANL) proposed tritium venting scheduled to begin tomorrow, September 13, 2025. Given your strong commitment to the health and well-being of New Mexico’s children, most recently demonstrated through your initiative to guarantee no-cost universal child care to all New Mexicans – we urge you to act quickly to protect children who stand to be the most impacted by LANL’s actions this weekend.
As you know, tritium is a highly radioactive isotope of ordinary, non-radioactive hydrogen. Given its structure, tritium bonds very easily to water, creating a vapor that is highly absorbable by the human body, pervading every cell. Tritium can be very dangerous if inhaled and has been shown to cause cancer, genetic mutations and birth defects. The amount of tritium LANL proposes to vent is three-times more tritium than would be dumped into the Pacific Ocean from the Fukushima nuclear power plant in Japan over the course of thirty years.
Notably, the dose to an infant from tritiated water vapor is estimated to be over three times greater than the dose to any adult expected to be exposed on Saturday. LANL has never considered the impacts to children from this project.
Rather than address LANL’s gross mismanagement of its nuclear waste, the New Mexico Environment Department, just a few days ago, made a rushed and reckless decision to authorize LANL’s venting, regardless of the uncertainty, the lack of adequate infrastructure to notify the public in the event of an emergency, and LANL’s disregard for the impacts of creating contaminated rain water, even in the face of rain forecasted for Saturday afternoon.
As the state’s only exclusively environmental-justice focused law center, the New Mexico Environmental Law Center has been engaging with communities impacted by LANL’s toxic legacy for over three decades. NMED’s most recent decision only perpetuates the same environmental and cultural violence LANL has inflicted upon communities since LANL’s creation. We are calling on you to do the right thing for New Mexico’s children and put a stop to LANL’s upcoming tritium venting.
Respectfully,
Dr. Virginia Necochea
Executive Director

title: Privacy Policy
text:
THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL LAW CENTER — PRIVACY POLICIES
The New Mexico Environmental Law Center is committed to protecting the privacy of our members, supporters and all visitors to our website.
NMELC Website Visitors
To help us improve our website, we may gather information about visitors to our website such as the pages visited, the amount of time spent on the site, the kind of browser used and the referring web page that brought you to our website. Absolutely no personal information is collected.
Click-Through URLS
In some of our e-mail communications, we use a “click-through URL” linked to content on our websites. When users click one of these URLs, they pass through a separate web server before arriving at the destination page on our website. We may track this click-through data to help us determine interest in particular topics and measure the effectiveness of our communications. If you prefer not to be tracked in this way, you should not click text or graphic links in the e-mail messages.
NMELC Website Purchases and Donations
For visitors purchasing merchandise or giving donations via the NMELC website, we collect information such as your name, address, telephone number, credit card information and your e-mail address on our secure transaction form. This information is necessary to fulfill your request and, if necessary, to communicate with you about your request. We will add your name and address to our database to keep you informed of our work and of the progress of our cases.
Sharing Information with Third Parties
The New Mexico Environmental Law Center does not share your personal information with third parties.
Opt-Out
If you do not want your information added to our database or if you do not wish to receive updates about our work, please contact us at nmelc@nmelc.org.
Have Questions?
If you have any questions regarding our Privacy Policy, please feel free to contact Elizabeth Lee at elee@nmelc.org.

title: Las Cruces Fire Department fights apartment blaze, no injuries reported
text:
Las Cruces Fire Department fights apartment blaze, no injuries reported
LAS CRUCES, N.M. (KFOX14/CBS4) — The Las Cruces Fire Department started the new year battling an apartment complex fire-- luckily, no one was injured.
According to LCFD, just after 7 p.m. on Thursday, emergency crews responded to an apartment complex fire on the 200 block of W. Madrid Ave., near N. Main Street.
Responding crews described the scene as "heavy fire coming from a downstairs apartment unit," and tackled the flames while looking for people inside.
LCFD stated the fire was put under control in five minutes, preventing it from spreading into other apartments.
Fortunately, no injuries were reported.
What caused the fire? That question is still under investigation.

title: ATV rollover near Rio Grande River trail leaves four injured, one in serious condition
text:
ATV rollover near Rio Grande River trail leaves four injured, one in serious condition
SUNLAND PARK, N.M. (KFOX14/CBS4) — Four people were hospitalized-- one in serious condition-- after an all-terrain vehicle rolled over near the Rio Grande River trail Thursday night.
According to the Sunland Park Fire Department, emergency crews responded to an ATV rollover after the vehicle reportedly fell into a canal just off the river at around 8:23 p.m.
A total of four people were injured, but one of them, a man in his early 20s, reportedly suffered serious injuries and had to be flown out of the area and rushed to the hospital by an El Paso Fire Department helicopter.
The other three injured were a girl in her late teens, a boy in his mid-teens and another boy just described as a minor.
Their injuries were described as "non-life-threatening."
Regarding what caused the rollover, the Sunland Park fire believes that the ATV riders were going fast while being unfamiliar with the territory.
Dona Ana County Fire and Rescue also helped.

title: UFC Holly Holmes returns to boxing, facing El Paso's rising star Stephanie Han
text:
UFC Holly Holmes returns to boxing, facing El Paso's rising star Stephanie Han
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — UFC legend and former boxing world champion Holly Holmes is set to face El Paso's undefeated Stephanie Han for the WBA lightweight title this weekend in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
Holmes, 44, is the most prominent opponent Han has encountered in her 11-0 career.
Known for her legendary UFC career, Holmes was a bantamweight world champion and famously knocked out Ronda Rousey, earning multiple accolades in 2015.
Meanwhile, 35-year-old Han has been active and successful in her boxing career.
This marks Holmes' second return to boxing after a 12-year hiatus for her UFC career.
The fight is scheduled for 6 p.m. El Paso time and will be available on DAZN.

title: Texas Western Hall to open as UTEP closes Liberal Arts Building for renovations
text:
Texas Western Hall to open as UTEP closes Liberal Arts Building for renovations
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — The University of Texas at El Paso is set to implement changes to some class schedules starting this month.
The university announced that the new Texas Western Hall will open next semester, while the longstanding Liberal Arts Building will close.
To accommodate more classes, UTEP will shift morning courses to a Monday, Wednesday, Friday schedule with 50-minute classes.
University officials stated that this change will allow for more than 200 additional course sections each semester, aiding students in staying on track to graduate.

title: Trump's $50 billion healthcare boost targets crisis in rural America
text:
Trump's $50 billion healthcare boost targets crisis in rural America
WASHINGTON (TNND) — An unprecedented federal investment is on its way to rural communities across the nation to help improve healthcare.
The Trump administration is doling out $50 billion in awards in all 50 states.
Dr. Mehmet Oz, who is the administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said it is the largest program of its kind.
“The $50 billion represents a 50% increase in the amount of money they were putting into rural areas for Medicaid,” Oz said during an interview with The National News Desk Taylor Murray on Friday. “And just to put it in context, Taylor, if you live in rural America, your life expectancy is shorter. We’re having a major problem in this country because your zip codes are dictating your life expectancy. You don’t have access to care. There’s not availability of newer technologies. We have problems with maternity mortality rates -- all kinds of problems.”
Oz said that’s why President Donald Trump, along with Congress, is giving $50 billion -- $1 billion to each state – over the course of five years. He said the point of the money is not to pay the bills, but to revamp the program and get to the root cause of why it’s not functional.
“For example, can we improve the technology that’s available so you get tele-medicine or even technology within hospitals so they can take better care of patients?” Oz said. “How do we connect the bigger hospitals to the smaller hospitals? How do we get people to go work in rural America?”
Oz said much of what holds back rural America to be healthy are “old-fashioned rules that just need to be changed.”
For more, watch the video player above or visit The National News Desk’s YouTube channel for Murray's full interview with Oz.

title: Potential fraud in Minnesota COVID-era lending programs
text:
Minnesota faces $400 million fraud probe over COVID-era pandemic loans; Trump responds
The Small Business Administration (SBA) has suspended 6,900 Minnesota borrowers over suspected fraudulent activity related to COVID-era lending programs.
These borrowers were collectively approved for approximately 7,900 loans, totaling roughly $400 million, according to SBA Administrator Kelly Loeffler.
Loeffler described the situation as "a complex scheme that was setup to defraud taxpayers, our federal government of needed funds that would have gone out during Covid for hungry families, for children, small businesses."
President Donald Trump says his administration won't stop until they figure out what happened in Minnesota.
“Actually, I view that as a reason for a good new year because we’re going to get to the bottom of [it], we’re going to get that money back. It’s all coming back," he said.
In response to these findings, the SBA will pause over $5.5 million in federal annual support to Minnesota, citing concerns about oversight failures. The implicated borrowers are now banned from all future SBA loan programs, including disaster assistance, effective immediately. Cases will be referred to federal law enforcement for potential prosecution and repayment.
The SBA's actions are part of a broader federal effort to address pandemic-era relief fraud. Multiple federal agencies, including the FBI and Department of Homeland Security, have launched investigations into related schemes in Minnesota.

title: Trump uses veto power to clap back at Indigenous tribe for Alligator Alcatraz lawsuit
text:
Trump uses veto power to clap back at Indigenous tribe for Alligator Alcatraz lawsuit
OCHOPEE, Fla. (CBS12) — President Trump used his veto power to "clap back" at a South Florida Indigenous tribe as the legal battles surrounding Alligator Alcatraz remain in limbo.
Alligator Alcatraz is the detention center deep in Florida’s Everglades.
The Miccosukee Tribe, whose reservation is the facility’s closest neighbor, is suing state and federal officials.
President Trump, with his pen, has just thrown a bucket of cold water on a bill that would have expanded tribal land and given the Miccosukees’ flood protection for one of their small villages-- from the Department of the Interior.
In his veto notice, Trump writes:
despite seeking funding and special treatment from the federal government, the Miccosukee tribe has actively sought to obstruct reasonable immigration policies that the American people decisively voted for when I was elected."
For its part, the tribe says it is just trying to protect sacred land and the delicate ecosystem of the Everglades.
Congress can override the veto: That would take a two-thirds majority in the House and the Senate, but it's unclear if there’s any hope for that.
If Capitol Hill fights the President on this issue, it could create tension inside the Republican party heading into a midterm election year, but the bill passed with bipartisan support before landing on the President’s desk.
The Miccosukee Tribe has partnered with environmental groups and several prominent Florida democrats to sue the agencies running Alligator Alcatraz.
The camp was built to hold thousands of illegal immigrants, but according to reports, typically there’s less than a thousand detainees at the facility.

title: DC Pipe Bomb suspect will remain locked up ahead of trial
text:
DC Pipe Bomb suspect will remain locked up ahead of trial
WASHINGTON (7News) — The man accused of planting bombs outside the Republican and Democratic National Committee headquarters in D.C. will remain behind bars as he awaits trial, according to a judge's ruling Friday.
This ruling comes after Brian Cole appeared before a federal judge on Tuesday for a detention hearing. Cole is accused of planting the bombs on the eve of the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.
RELATED | Pipe bomb suspect appears in federal court, defense seeks pretrial release
Attorneys for the 30-year-old requested that he go under house arrest at his grandmother's house in Gainesville, saying he poses no danger to the public and an ankle monitor will give the Court reasonable assurance he won't flee.
Prosecutors argued that Cole is a danger to the community, pointing to the bomb-making materials they said he bought as recently as three years ago, that he hid at home and the hundreds of times they said that he wiped his cell phone clean.
The judge ultimately sided with the prosecution.
"The court is keenly aware that pretrial detention must be 'the carefully limited exception' due in no small part to the fact that Mr. Cole, like all defendants, is entitled to the presumption of innocence at this juncture. And the Court understands its 'grave constitutional obligation to ensure that the facts and circumstances of each case warrant this exceptional treatment.' But based on the Court's careful consideration of the relevant factors that govern its determination, this case fits that bill," the ruling from Judge Matthew Sharbaugh reads.
Read the full ruling below:
A recent court filing from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Columbia states Cole confessed two hours into his interview with the FBI after investigators showed him a still image of the suspect from surveillance video close in time to the planting of the bombs.
According to prosecutors' filing, Cole denied to investigators that his actions were directed toward Congress or related to the proceedings scheduled to take place on Jan. 6, when the 2020 presidential election results were supposed to be certified but were ultimately delayed by rioters who broke into the U.S. Capitol Building, alleging the election was rigged. The bombs never went off and were discovered the following afternoon.
Cole told investigators that "something just snapped" after “watching everything, just everything getting worse," states the court filing, amid questions raised by President Donald Trump and Republicans about the results of the 2020 presidential election. There was no evidence of widespread voter fraud in the election.
Cole's charges include transporting an explosive device in interstate commerce with the intent to kill, injure, or intimidate any individual or unlawfully to damage or destroy any building, vehicle, or other real or personal property. He is also charged with attempted malicious destruction by means of fire and explosive materials.

Robert Holguin spoke with some of the key players in the production at the rehearsal.

Native El Pasoan Cristina Ibarra, is a filmmaker who was recently awarded a 2021 MacArthur Fellow Award.

Holguin speaks to the newly appointed commissioner of the International Boundary and Water Commission a long-time El Pasoans who earned herself a presidential appointment. Holguin then talks to Angela Mora, the director of the El Paso Public Health Department, who is in charge of the city COVID-19 response.

In episode 45 of Built In the Borderland, Ben Miranda of The Steven A. Cohen Military Family Clinic atEndeavors, talks about providing mental health to local veterans amid the Afghanistan attacks. Catch Built in the Borderland every Sunday on KFOX14 at 10:30 p. m.

On Tuesday, which marked the 2nd anniversary of the shooting, the city unveiled its healing garden in honor of the victims.

Do My Job: Clowning around with Cirque du Soleil
Cirque du Solieil was back in the Borderland this weekend with the show OVO. The show takes place at The Don Haskins Center from March 12 through March 15. As performers prepared for their six shows, I got to rehearse with the clowns. One of the main clown performers taught me his routine. The cast of OVO is comprised of 52 performing artists from 14 countries specializing in many acrobatic acts. OVO is now a Cirque du Soleil classic.
5 years ago
Do My Job: Hillside Coffee & Donut Co.
Hillside Coffee & Donut Co. is known for its square donuts. With locations on both the west and the east sides of town, all El Pasoans have a chance to get the Hillside experience. I visited the location in west El Paso, it's perched in Montecillo, to become a donut-maker for the day. Beyond the coffee, espresso and tea beverages Hillside serves up-- it also has several flavors of donuts to choose from with flavors as unique as their shape.
5 years ago
Do My Job: Streamline Auto & Cycle Collision
Streamline Auto & Cycle Collision has two locations -- one in Central and the other in East El Paso. Both are owned by Annette Hernandez, a woman who's been in the automotive industry for more than 20 years. Hernandez manages the Central location, while her daughter manages the one in East El Paso. She tells KFOX14 being the boss in a male-dominated industry was tough at first. Hernandez said there were many times when customers did not take her seriously as the manager and owner.

title: Pedestrian killed in hit-and-run on US-54 in El Paso; police seek information
text:
Pedestrian killed in hit-and-run on US-54 in El Paso; police seek information
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — El Paso police are investigating a deadly hit-and-run incident that occurred on US-54 North near Ellerthorpe in Northeast El Paso Friday morning.
The Special Traffic Investigations unit reported that 36-year-old Miguel Eduardo Rodriguez stopped his vehicle at Gateway North and walked to the shoulder of the highway, where he was struck by an unknown vehicle.
The vehicle fled the scene, and Rodriguez was transported to the hospital, where he died from his injuries.
Authorities believe the vehicle may have damage to the front right corner.
They urge anyone with information to contact the El Paso Police Department at 915-832-4400 or Crime Stoppers of El Paso at 915-566-8477 to remain anonymous.
This marks the 61st traffic fatality of 2025, compared to 68 at this time last year.

title: What's Driving You Crazy: What happens next following road damage from a crash?
text:
What's Driving You Crazy: What happens next following road damage from a crash?
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — What happens next following road damage from a crash? That's what's driving viewers crazy this week.
A crash on I-10 near Geronimo on Sunday has raised questions about the process for addressing road damage.
The incident, which went viral on social media, involved a vehicle veering across lanes, hitting a guardrail, and knocking down a massive exit sign before catching fire on the access road.
The crash closed down the area and was cleared after 12 hours.
RECOMMENDED: What's Driving You Crazy: School traffic congestion frustrates El Paso drivers
Officials from the Texas Department of Transportation have assessed the site and determined that a new sign will need to be installed, and guardrail repairs made.
Lauren Macias-Cervantes with TxDOT stated, "There is no estimated timeframe on replacing the sign at this point. The new sign will need to be designed, the area will be assessed for new installation, then the replacement can be scheduled."
Regarding potential closures for sign installation, TxDOT noted, "It is too soon to tell, but traffic control can vary from lane to full closures on sign installations. We are currently analyzing the location and evaluating the need for any temporary signage."
Guardrail repairs have been postponed until 2026.

title: What's Driving You Crazy: School traffic congestion frustrates El Paso drivers
text:
What's Driving You Crazy: School traffic congestion frustrates El Paso drivers
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — School traffic blocks roadways during student drop-off. That's what's driving one viewer crazy this week.
A viewer contacted KFOX14, stating in part, "Harmony school on Joe Battle is blocking 1 lane of Joe Battle ---There is no need to block traffic on a busy 2 lane road when all the school has to do is open either of 2 gates to allow parents to exit the school. One in Amesbury and the other on Addison."
In response to these concerns, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) clarified that school locations are determined by local zoning authorities, not TxDOT.
Harmony Public Schools stated that their traffic plan, reviewed and approved by TxDOT, includes a staggered drop-off and dismissal schedule to reduce congestion. The school also collaborates with the El Paso County Sheriff's Office to manage vehicle flow on Joe Battle Blvd.

2 years ago

3 years ago
Rhinos to host free summer game, cancer research fundraiser on Saturday
The Rhinos will host their first Black & Orange All-Star Game on Saturday at 7 pm. Admission is free, and seating is first come, first served. The doors will open at 6:30 pm and the puck drops at 7:00. The game will include promotions like Jersey off the Back, Dance for Your Dinner, Chuck-A-Puck, and more. Fans will also have a chance to skate with players for free once the game has concluded.
3 years ago
El Paso Rhinos advance to playoffs, host free game Saturday
The El Paso Rhinos have advanced to playoffs and will be hosting a free game on Saturday. After topping the Oklahoma City Ice Hawks last weekend, the Rhinos’ NA3HL team has advanced to the Fraser Cup Division Finals and will host the Texas RoadRunners on Saturday. The puck will drop at 7 p. m. , and Sunday at 4:30 pm, if necessary. To thank fans for their continued support throughout the season, El Paso Rhinos will hold the game this weekend for free.
3 years ago
El Paso Rhinos to host three playoff series games for free
The El Paso Rhinos NA3HL team will host the first round of Fraser Cup Playoffs this Friday, Saturday, and, if necessary, Sunday. In appreciation for El Paso’s support this season, all three games are free, officials with the El Paso Rhinos said. After finishing the regular season in third place with a record of 33-13-1 (W-L-OTL), El Paso will welcome the second-place Oklahoma City Ice Hawks. The difference between the Rhinos’ and Ice Hawks’ records is just one overtime loss.
5 years ago
Upcoming El Paso Rhinos season cancelled
The most decorated team in the city will not be returning to action in the near future. In a statement released Tuesday night, theWestern States Hockey League announced they will be cancelling the 2020-21 season. The announcement comes after the 2020 playoffs were cancelled back in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The El Paso Rhinos, the leagues defending Thorne Cup Champions, have yet to comment on the leagues decision but said a statement should be released in the coming days.
5 years ago
Rhinos Visit Children's Hospital and will Shave Heads for Childhood Cancer Research
To end the regular season, the Rhinos will also host their tenth annual St. Baldrick’s series. On Saturday, Mar. 7, the players, the coaching and training staff, youth hockey players, and UTEP Hockey players will shave their heads to fight childhood cancer. During the game, fans are invited to bid on a Rhino’s or Miner’s hair and following the game, auction winners will take the first swipe of each shavee’s hair. All proceeds benefit the St. Baldrick’s Foundation.
5 years ago
El Paso in the running to be next Kraft Hockeyville USA city
El Paso could be the next Kraft Hockeyville USA city and earn the right to host a pre-season NHL game and receive $150,000 to upgrade the region’s most popular hockey rink. The El Paso County Events Center – home of the back-to-back Thorne Cup Champions El Paso Rhinos – is in the hunt to earn the prestigious designation and needs the help of the community to get it done.
6 years ago
El Paso Rhinos spread love of the game to youth hockey players
One night a week on the Event Center ice, a group of young men strap on their skates, pad up and hit the rink. But these guys still have a little way to go before they make the big leagues. “This is our Junior Rhinos program. It’s kind of our learn-to-play program,” said Tom Herman, the youth hockey director for the El Paso Hockey Association. The Junior Rhinos are the introductory class in the El Paso Hockey Association.
5 years ago
2019-20 season for El Paso Rhinos comes to halt in light of coronavirus pandemic
The Western States Hockey League was among American sports organizations to cancel all scheduled games amid the coronavirus. El Paso Rhinos are part of the league. The team will have to stop its season. The Rhinos' home playoff games scheduled for March 13 through the 15 and March 20 through 22 will not be played. The Thorne Cup Final games planned for the end of March are also cancelled.
6 years ago
2020 Holidays at the Rink; schedule and coupon
SCHEDULE FOR PUBLIC SKATE. Hit the ice at "Holidays at the Rink! " Enjoy indoor ice skating at theEl Paso County Coliseum Events Center at 4100 E Paisano Drive. KFOX14 and CBS4 are teaming up with the El Paso Rhinos to invite the community to come out and skate on the largest rink in the area. Regular admission is $12 which includes your skates. Get $2 off admission when you present this coupon. Pick up your coupon at any Circle K; no purchase needed. Coupon: Holidays at the Rink.
6 years ago
Rhinos Power Play: Sebastian Jovicic
The El Paso Rhinos (13-1-1) host the Dallas Snipers this weekend and before every Rhinos home series, we go one-on-one with a Rhino for the KFOX 14/CBS 4 Rhinos Power Play.
6 years ago
First-ever twins play for El Paso Rhinos
It’s never a surprise seeing an El Pasoan on the Rhinos hockey team, but the team has never had twin brothers from the Sun City on the roster at the same time, until now. “To be able to be part of the team and dress in the locker room, it's very special to us,” said Jonathan Clement. It’s a dream turned reality for the Clement brothers. “You grow up and you watch these guys at a young age, and you idolize them,” said Jonathan Clement.
6 years ago
Rhinos Power Play for Oct. 24
With the El Paso Rhinos making their home debut of the new season vs the Pueblo Bulls, the Power Play also makes it season debut. This week, forward Easton Easterson sits down with KFOX 14 Sports Anchor Patrick Chalvire but instead of answering the questions, he's playing reporter.
5 years ago
El Paso Rhinos find new home with NAHL
Weeks after the El Paso Rhinos announced they would be competing in the Fall despite not being associated with a league, the North American Hockey League (NAHL) announced that its Board of Governors approved the membership application for the Rhinos. The El Paso Rhinos will compete in the South Division beginning in the 2021-22 season and play out of the El Paso County Events Center. The team will also join the North American 3 Hockey League (NA3HL) for the 2020-21 season.

title: Doña Ana County approves $165 billion AI data center despite protests and calls for delay
text:
Doña Ana County approves $165 billion AI data center despite protests and calls for delay
LAS CRUCES, N.M. (KFOX14/CBS4) — Dona Ana County Commissioners approved the $165 billion artificial intelligence data center in Santa Teresa.
On Friday, during a county meeting, Project Jupiter was approved in a four-to-one vote, amidst community protest.
County leaders emphasized that Friday's vote is not a final approval but rather a decision on whether to authorize the issuance of industrial revenue bonds.
County documents indicate that commissioners will consider authorizing up to $165 billion in these bonds.
The project, which is led by Borderplex Digital Assets, includes plans for a data center and related facilities, which leaders say could bring thousands of construction jobs and hundreds of permanent positions.
"Project Jupiter represents the largest potential commercial project in Doña Ana County's history, and actually one of the largest in the state's history," said Stephen Lopez, Doña Ana County Assistant County Manager. He added that the project could bring high-paying jobs and workforce development opportunities to southern New Mexico.
However, not all local leaders are convinced.
RELATED: Dona Ana County residents urge delay on $165 billion AI data center
The City of Sunland Park requested a delay in Friday's vote.
Mayor Javier Perea expressed concerns about the project's impact on the city, stating, "We're finding out information at the same time that, you know, press releases are being released and that doesn't cover a lot of information."
Furthermore, community activists, like Daisy Maldonado of Empower NM, also wanted the process to be paused.
"To get our commissioners to hear our voice, and for them to really take our concerns seriously, so that they don't vote yes on Friday but in fact delay it to get more information," said Maldonado.
Maldonado highlighted the lack of awareness among residents about the project and pointed out missing analyses.
"There's a missing economic analysis, there's a missing environmental analysis, and certainly, there's a missing community voice, and community buy-in for this project," she said.
"There's other ways that they can mitigate this, delay the vote, they could vote no, and guess what, the companies can come back and apply again."

title: Project Jupiter ignites debate: Economic tech boom or ecological bane for Borderland?
text:
Project Jupiter ignites debate: Economic tech boom or ecological bane for Borderland?
EL PASO, TEXAS (KFOX14/CBS4) — Meta’s announcement of a new AI data center in El Paso comes just one month after Project Jupiter — another massive data center planned next door in Doña Ana County — took a major step forward.
Here’s the background behind that project and how we got here.
Known as Project Jupiter, this artificial intelligence data center is expected to bring significant investment and job opportunities to the region.
However, it also raises questions about water usage, energy demands, and community impact.
RECOMMENDED: Meta to build $1.5 billion AI data center in El Paso, creating nearly 2,000 jobs
Project Jupiter is a key component of Stargate, a national pipeline project aimed at expanding the U.S.'s capacity to train and run massive AI systems.
The initiative, announced by President Trump in January alongside tech giants OpenAI, Oracle, and SoftBank, involves a $500 billion investment across the country.
Five AI data centers are planned, including locations in:
- Santa Teresa, New Mexico
- Abilene, Texas
- Milam County, Texas
- Shackelford County, Texas
- Lordstown, Ohio
Developers chose the desert location for its open land, available infrastructure, and access to regional energy corridors.
In September, Doña Ana County commissioners voted to move the project forward after several public meetings.
RELATED: Doña Ana County approves $165 billion AI data center despite protests and calls for delay
While some residents support the project for its potential to create jobs and boost the local economy, others express concerns about environmental impacts.
One supporter highlighted the opportunities for youth and workforce development, saying, "Both the opportunities for youth, for good workforce, and again, for New Mexico to participate in the project explosion that's happening around the country and around the world."
Conversely, a concerned resident argued, "It's just going to be another hazard. We already have the land field, we have a power plant, we have a cycle. They just come, private companies come, make money and they do. It's just a hazard."
According to the project website, Project Jupiter and Stargate promise to:
- Limit water use to domestic employee needs
- Build and supply their own power
- Invest up to $165 billion in Doña Ana County
- Deliver $300 million in direct payments to the county
- Create over 2,500+ construction jobs and 750+ permanent jobs
Despite these assurances, many in the community remain vigilant, watching to see if these promises are fulfilled once construction begins.

title: Immigration raid in El Paso neighborhood leaves residents shaken
text:
Immigration raid in El Paso neighborhood leaves residents shaken
El Paso, TX (KFOX14/CBS4) — An apparent immigration raid in Far East El Paso has left residents rattled after witnessing what they described as a chaotic scene involving unmarked ICE vehicles and the apprehension of workers building homes.
Christian Garcia, a local resident, recounted the event, saying, "I saw an unmarked vehicle parked, like, two houses down."
Garcia described authorities descending on workers off Bob Hope Drive, noting, "He creeped up on the workers. And he already had one guy detained, and he had them by the by his hands, and he already had them by his back, and he wasn't letting them go."
Garcia shared footage and photos of the arrests, which included the use of a helicopter, as some men reportedly fled the site.
"There was a bunch of, like, people in military vests and they were identifiable, the officers themselves, it's just the cars they pulled up and it was like normal cars you see every day," Garcia said. "And they pulled up and they just started harassing these people."
An anonymous neighbor expressed shock and devastation, stating, "These are our community workers. They help build our schools, our houses, and they ensure safety of our houses. And especially for this to happen on New Year's Eve, it's it's just devastating. They're hard working people. Honestly, most of them do not have criminal records."
Alan Surratt, another resident, shared mixed feelings about the incident.
"You know, I don't know. I have mixed feelings about it, to be honest. I mean, these guys are working. I don't think they're criminals, but you never know," he said.
KFOX14 reached out to ICE and DHS for comment or details surrounding the event, but the agencies have not responded in time for this report.
Garcia expressed his frustration, saying, "It's unreal. Something real I can't put into words. Still, now I'm shaking a little bit, like it's all coming back to me. What I experienced and I don't know, it's an injustice."

title: Beloved Borderland artist grapples with cancer diagnosis
text:
Beloved Borderland artist grapples with cancer diagnosis
EL PASO, Texas (KFOX14/CBS4) — For more than five decades, Hal Marcus has been a visual ambassador to the Borderland, capturing its spirit and its color on canvas. Now, Marcus is entering a new chapter: one shaped by a cancer diagnosis that changed everything.
Earlier this year, doctors told him he may have only months to live. But instead of retreating, the 72-year-old is doing what he’s always done, turning life into art and using this moment to fuel a powerful new phase of his creative work.
“I am counting on a huge miracle, granted, but I'm also preparing for going on a long journey,” said Marcus during a recent interview at his studio in Sunset Heights.
Marcus has been making art nearly every day since he was sixteen. A cancer diagnosis hasn’t changed that. If anything, it has only sharpened his focus.
“They gave me six months to live. It was four months ago, and I'm more healthy now than I was four months ago when they diagnosed me,” said Marcus. “At least that's my perception. I haven't put like an x-ray camera into my body, but I'm telling you, I'm here, I'm alive. I wake up at two o'clock in the morning and go in my studio and I'm creating new art, and I'm here with you. So, I think that that's proof.”
Hal’s life has been marked by both commercial success and creative freedom. For more than thirty years, he’s owned and operated the Hal Marcus Gallery. He’s also helped create the Sunset Parlor, a space for live music, wellness and community. But since the diagnosis, the urgency to keep creating has intensified.
“I finally, just like three weeks ago, came up with the idea that my medicine is to do whatever I need to do to make me happy, to enjoy every single moment and to spend as much time in my studio,” said Marcus. “And that's my medicine.”
WATCH:
Marcus says much of his resilience comes from the people around him.
Supporters, collaborators and friends who continue to show up. One of them is Luke Lowenfield, who partnered with Hal to create a series of children’s books rooted in imagination and kindness.
“What he's taught me is that ‘Luke, if you love to write, you've got to write every day. You've got to do everything as a writer. That's what you're here to do.’ And so, I think that's going to be his legacy is he has modeled for us all as an artist. What an artist does, lives with passion and artistry every day and does everything as an artist,” said Lowenfield. ”And so, I think his legacy will be to tune in to your heart's desire, tune in to the purpose for which you are here and do that with the people that you love all day, every day. Commit yourself to vote yourself to that.”
And then there’s his family.
“I mean, it's such an interesting thing because I do have those two parts of me where the daughter wants to control and fix and tell them what to eat and tell them what to do and freaking out,” said his daughter Leilainia Marcus. “But then I have to step back and be the human, having a human experience with this person I admire and look up to as not attached to him as my father. And I just feel so much beauty. So much beauty in the way that he's experienced life and that he's transformed his own life and my life and the people around him. He walks into a room and the energy of the room changes. And that's been since before I can remember.
And his wife, Patricia Medici, who for decades has been the steady hand behind the business side of Hal Marcus.
“That's one of the things Hal has a great support team with his family and his close friends. And he revels in that. He knows it,” said Medici. “And it makes him happy too.”
Lately, Hal’s work has taken a new direction. Birds have become a central theme. Symbols of movement, fragility, and freedom.
“That's a part of my evolution at the stage in my life where I'm getting closer to heaven or I'm getting tuned in more with the freedom,” Marcus said. “I'm saying is that whatever your issue is and you always wanted to do it, do it now.”
He’s also cutting up his old shirts, repurposing the fabric into layered, mixed-media panels. Pieces of his own history stitched directly into the work.
And now, Hal is choosing to share his diagnosis publicly. Not for sympathy. Not for pity. But as an invitation. A reminder to do the thing you love, while you still can.
“If people ask me what can I do to help you, because they're always saying, ‘Can I bring you something? Can I do something for you?’ Well, (my daughter) had a good idea. She'd tell me, ‘Just tell everybody to do what they love doing.’ You know, and whatever obstacles in your way, forget that, just do what you love doing. And if they can understand that message, that's going to help me out a lot,” Marcus said. “You know, because I don't need anything, you know. I mean, I need your love and your prayers, yeah, but, you know, I'm a happy camper.”
For Hal Marcus, that means showing up to the studio. Every day. And continuing to tell the story of this place and his place within it, for as long as he’s able.

Meet your D.C. Reporter
Reena Diamante is a reporter for Spectrum News, based in the Washington D.C. bureau.
She covers Congress, the White House, the Supreme Court, and national politics with an emphasis on the Texas delegation. Since joining the D.C. bureau in 2021, Reena has closely followed the contentious debate over U.S. immigration policy, the effects of the Supreme Court's historic decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, and the first gun safety legislation in decades following the Uvalde school shooting. She also reports on the political campaigns in Texas and has traveled to border communities to cover key races.
Reena is a graduate of the Columbia Journalism School. She was born in Davao City, Philippines, and immigrated to New York City as a child. She began her career as a photographer and producer for Spectrum News NY1 in New York City. Her field highlights include the 2016 presidential nominating conventions in Cleveland and Philadelphia, the presidential debate at Hofstra University, and Pope Francis’ historic New York City visit.
Additionally, she previously worked as a state politics reporter covering the Texas legislature for Spectrum News in Austin. In Texas, she covered breaking news including the death of First Lady Barbara Bush and the mass shootings in Santa Fe and Sutherland Springs.
Her reporting on Texas' abortion restrictions, the political response to the 2021 deadly winter storm in Texas and 20 years since September 11 attacks garnered Regional Emmy nominations. She is a recipient of a Regional Edward R. Murrow award for her storytelling into the little-known history of suffragists and the site of the Supreme Court.

title: Requesting Legal Assistance
text:
Requesting Legal Assistance
Note: the Law Center is currently only considering requests for assistance on a limited basis.
We at the New Mexico Environmental Law Center are committed to working with communities to address environmental justice issues. We are the only legal organization in New Mexico providing free or low cost legal representation in environmental justice cases.
Please read the following before requesting assistance.
We will evaluate and may accept a request for assistance if it meets any of the following criteria:
- There is significant threat to human health, air, water or land.
- Environmental justice issues are presented; everyone is entitled to a clean and healthy environment regardless of their race, socio-economic status, ethnicity, gender, disability or tribal affiliation.
- The case could establish a precedent that would help other communities.
- You or your community do not already have legal representation.
- You or your community do not have resources to otherwise obtain legal representation.
- The New Mexico Environmental Law Center has adequate resources and the capacity to provide high quality legal services.
We do not accept the following types of cases:
- Disputes between private landowners;
- Disputes between a single individual or business owner and a regulatory agency, county, city, state, tribal or federal government;
- Criminal law matters;
- General civil law matters, such as contract disputes, consumer law issues, government benefits, divorce or child custody, landlord/tenant disputes, tax issues, or probate and wills;
- Personal injury, medical malpractice or toxic torts.
